Choosing a president
Perhaps the first group on campus to sense the
necessity for new leadership at the top was the students.
For years they complained about the dearth of contact
between themselves and their president to the point that
Lincoln Gordon became a man little known and still less
respected am ong_ the student body. "There aren't many

administrators last week, while discussing Gordon's
troubles, and indeed much of the appeal of Yale's
charismatic leader lies in his popularity with the
students. Effective leadership at Hopkins must enjoy
the same popularity.
It goes without saying that the University's new
president must have the respect of the faculty. It was
the lack of such respect that rendered Gordon
ineffective and eventually led to his resignation. A
president must work well with his faculty, leaving them
convinced that the administration of their school is in
good hands while providing leadership in the academic
fields.
The Board of Trustees has apparantly set up a search
committee to look for a new president. It was wise for
the executive committee of the Board, following their
acceptance of Gordon's resignation, to call in faculty
members for discussions about possible interim
successors. Hopefully, this is an indication that the
search committee will have close contact with the
faculty, though it is suggested that this not be limited to
senior faculty members. The non-tenured group here at
Homewood should also be consulted about any possible
candidates.
Still, it is clear that Gordon's successor must also be
acceptable to the students, a group to whom the Board of
Trustees has never been very close. It is vital that the
opinions of both undergraduates and graduates be
actively sought on this matter. Indeed, it seems clear
that it could only be helpful to have formal
representation for senior and junior faculty, and

Male bias
Women graduate students and faculty members are
prey to a variety of discriminatory practices at Hopkins.
Getting in to the University is only the first of many
obstacles which face women who seek an academic
career. For example, Hopkins is far behind most other
schools in the nation in the hiring of women faculty.
While the national average for female instructors is 54.7
percent, at Hopkins only 1.1 percent are women.
But worse, perhaps, especially for women grad
students, is the daily bias they have to face. All too often
they are treated as merely cute little additions to their
departments. Because of the ever-present double
standard, they have to be wary of working too closely
with male professors, and so they end up damaging their
career. Only equal treatment, then, can begin to end
male supremacy at Hopkins.

Perhaps the first group on campus to sense the
necessity for new leadership at the top was the students.
For years they complained about the dearth of contact
between themselves and their president to the point that
Lincoln Gordon became a man little known and still less
respected am ong_ the student body. "There aren't many

troubles, and indeed much of the appeal of Yale's
charismatic leader lies in his popularity with the
students. Effective leadership at Hopkins must enjoy
the same popularity.
It goes without saying that the University's new
president must have the respect of the faculty. It was
the lack of such respect that rendered Gordon
ineffective and eventually led to his resignation. A
president must work well with his faculty, leaving them
convinced that the administration of their school is in
good hands while providing leadership in the academic
fields.

the executive committee of the Board, following their
acceptance of Gordon's resignation, to call in faculty
members for discussions about possible interim
successors. Hopefully, this is an indication that the
search committee will have close contact with the
faculty, though it is suggested that this not be limited to
senior faculty members. The non-tenured group here at
Homewood should also be consulted about any possible
candidates.
Still, it is clear that Gordon's successor must also be
acceptable to the students, a group to whom the Board of
Trustees has never been very close. It is vital that the
opinions of both undergraduates and graduates be

Women graduate students and faculty members are
prey to a variety of discriminatory practices at Hopkins.
Getting in to the University is only the first of many
obstacles which face women who seek an academic
career. For example, Hopkins is far behind most other
schools in the nation in the hiring of women faculty.

departments. Because of the ever-present double
standard, they have to be wary of working too closely
with male professors, and so they end up damaging their
career. Only equal treatment, then, can begin to end
male supremacy at Hopkins.
